name: C O F F E E T O G R A P H E R
bio:
coffee is a culture. 
A journey. A ritual. A love story.
SITE: under reconstructtion

social_posts.post_text:
coffee be like fine art. 

I welcome myself back to the gram, after an unexpected hiatus that became highly intentional.

In this pause I've taken time to reimagine how I want to share stories to these squares and how I want to build upon a legacy of documenting specialty coffee and it's culture. 

so why is this squash dressed in pearls? come hear on @tiktok.
matcha gives me that, "I can feel your energy from two planets away" power.

Why does it seem treacherous that a slider is only ten images? Maybe that's why this is my first time doing one and it took a week to decide. 

Last summer I really began to adventure back into the public spaces of coffee shops after nearly twoish years of being home where the pandemic gifted me the time and space to discover my at-home ritual. 

As I did, I often went with just my phone for in and out experiences. And when I did, It ached to not have my camera with me, which would remind me how much I loved holding a physical instrument to capture images. 

March 19th, 2021 was the last time I was out of the country and the day the world shut down. One of the things I'm most excited about is traveling out of the country again with my cameras and back into new and favored spaces. 

These moments shared here are here not because of a 'best of' list. Instead they are here because something happened where the capture met a point in specific time that enriched my life, these occurrences are often unplanned and in the synchronicity of being. 

Among these, I had brilliant coffee, a conversation to remember, an epiphany, visual escape, laughter, an illustrious coffee date with a beautiful person, consolation and peace. 

In sharing these, I  campaign for 16 images to a slider so that I may include @offsetcoffeeco, @holaadioscoffeeshop,  @landtoseanyc, @neighborhood @dayglow and @cafe_demitasse. 

Oh the coffee places I'll go this year, catch me and my cameras if you can. #shotoniphone

If there's a classic story to be told of an Oaxcano with big dreams coming to America; staying with family, learning English, working as a dishwasher,  becoming a certified barista, and marrying the partner of a lifetime ,while saving for a dream, then we've found it. 

Under the bright Los Angeles sun on Montebello, Pilar and Marlon welcome me to their coffee casa where I learn of their story while drinking mochas, eating chilaquiles and listening to the sounds of Ebo Taylor, quietly thunder overhead.

Con Amor, The Coffeetographer 

now on the webzine:
'The Magic of Coffee with Cafe Santo'.

A couple dozen feet from the sand of the Pacific Ocean in Venice, California, there is a corner market front along a driveway whose interiors are illuminated by the light of the day and the eventual moonlight. 

If one went by its name only – Dudley’s Market – you might think it a fanciful grocer –  one of those hybrid shops curating specialties with food, wine, and alt beverages – the ones canned and bottled with packaging that is thoughtful, at times trendy and visually arousing.

While one can find specialties of fresh caught fish and wine – updated daily –  this market contains something humanely special: Christopher Nicely Abel, father, barista, and Lego builder,  who is at the helm of Hooked Venice, his coffee bar, within.

I chose this space, and his service, as my first Coffee for One of the year -  a retelling of my personal coffee date.

“We want people to swirl around this and get hooked,” said Nicely.

What is the 'this' and what did I get hooked on? Head to the webzine to read all about it.

I've come a long way from not liking espresso when I had my first demitasse in Italy years ago; I didn't understand it at all. 

now, I like it neat, with discernible flavor, balanced and with a side of seltzer - it's proper that way. 

this gave sweet plum up front and orange candy slices in the middle. once I chased it with the effervescence of seltzer water, and it's memory lingering with me, my hope was that, if only espresso could have a better narrative than what's often heard - bitter and acidic in America.

we're getting there!
you're an edifice that's like a ball and socket joint, the lines of your hips do not lie.

May I set the scene for this espresso root beer float? 

There was the caress of ocean in the air, which blew in from a raised garage door mere feet away. 

There was the blue and white tiles set against the sandy concrete floors that evoked the feeling of waves indoors. 

I shook the glass and the root beer swirled like a merry-go-round, around a center of  espresso and milk which made it whole.

Crushed jce, dainty like a slip, created an experience at once soft and intimate, just how I love it.  I was left floating, on a lingering taste of tootsie roll and light cream | @daydreamsurfshop |
Come along as I explore new coffee shop openings, seasonal menus and all the pretty tiled spaces.
If you've seen one coffee shop have you seen them all?  It's the people, art, music and conversations that make a space a cultural ecosystem.  Follow for exclusive moments from my adventures.

What does coffee taste like?  How does it feel? What memory does it incite? 
Is it like a kiss on the nape of your neck? Does it taste like your favorite Saturday morning cereal while you're nestled under a Moroccan throw? Does it take you to a dirt road in a foreign land where an aha! yielded unbridled joy?  Together, let's find out.

This is a story. 

I’ve stopped counting how many coffee shops I’ve been to. And I’ve stopped wondering how many times I’ll see the same frame of a coffee shop come across a timeline once it hits the questioning circuit of ‘have you been’?

Come viral or trend, what is most important, is that I haven’t stopped falling in love with them. 

However, I’ve come to realize that there’s an assumption, at times, that when one sees an image of a beautiful coffee shop, like this, it could be anticlimactic.  Seen it once, seen them all, right? I say, no; I even say wrong. 

I walked through @rhythmzeronyc doors to an idle espresso machine, soft lights and a lemon tart whose color yellow was like the cover art of Dope Lemon's Marinade which was then playing. 

Sound, as it can, filled the high ceiling room, making the space intoxicating, like a cologne whose dose, metered to the circumference of a fingerprint, lured me in close. Falling. 

Consciously, I wanted the embrace to deepen. I began conversation with the baristas at the counter which quickly included a shared story of friendship, punctuality and glee, because after a quick scan of the room, I could celebrate arriving earlier than my coffee date whose timing to our adventures I can only beat, if I sleep overnight at our destinations. 

(They are going to laugh when they read this, because the hyperbole is near true.) 

As I waited for them and my coffee, I recessed to one of the couches. I took in the scope, which includes an interior that is known to change every couple months. Falling. 

I saw towering frames of art; lines of leisure, heard milk coo, a glass clink, my name called, saw a couple meet and kiss, watched ceramics get deserted, eavesdropped on group taking over the middle table, and saw a spotted dog wag his tail. Falling. 

Much of that you don't see in this frame, but instead, this: the bar, that art, those lights. 

When I proffer what makes me want a visual document of being here or anywhere, it isn’t that I can capture what someone else saw, or all of what happened in the span of time spent. 

Instead, it is that i can frame the moment the falling in love began.
Coffee speaks to me because I listen.

coffee is a culture. 
A journey. A ritual. A love story.
SITE: under reconstructtion
